text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single framed miniature occupying the lower margin beneath a single column of text; bordered by a red and white foliate border on all sides; image isolated from text block with clear separation

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold reserved for divine realm (God’s throne and halo); ultramarine blue diaper ground provides a rich pictorial field; white used for angelic figure and highlights; green and red distinguish the saint’s garments; layered application with lead white highlights on faces and robes; minimal pigment oxidation, well-preserved contrasts between warm and cool tones

features: Vertical axis from God at apex down to angel and saint
Overlapping clouds create spatial separation of heavenly and earthly realms
Diagonal gesture from God’s hand to angel’s offering links the compartments
Saint positioned at left registers devotional stance facing upward
Corpselike rubble at lower right anchors martyrdom beneath celestial reception

decorative_elements: Diaper-patterned blue background with small gold bezants
Red and white foliate border with scrolling vine motif
Architectural Gothic micro-frame around God composed of pinnacles and trefoil arches

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in brown-black ink with varying line weight; bold contours around figures and delicate internal detail
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat areas of color with minimal hatching; lead white highlights on drapery folds and faces to suggest volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling (God larger and elevated), no attempt at linear perspective; depth indicated by overlapping clouds and ground plane

content_theme.scene_description: The miniature depicts a single hagiographic scene: on the left a standing saint with halo, clad in a green tunic and red mantle, right hand touching chest in devotional gesture and left hand slightly extended. At center an angel with nimbus and white robes steps from a rocky ledge, holding a golden disk (the soul) tipped upward. Above, God the Father sits within a Gothic micro-architecture borne on stylized clouds, reaching down with his right hand to transfer the soul to the angel. In the lower right, a mass of broken stones and red striations represent the aftermath of the martyrdom—either the ruined ground of execution or the crushed body awaiting divine rescue. The saint and angel occupy the terrestrial plane, separated from the heavenly throne by a dark blue diapered field. The saint’s scale is subordinate to the angel, whose gesture bridges earth and heaven. Costumes are rendered with fine fold lines; the heavenly figure’s wings are outlined in gold. The saint’s garments bear subtle green and red pigment layering; the angel is defined by pure white with minimal shading. A red and white scroll border encloses the scene, reinforcing its devotional function.

architectural: Gothic micro-architecture (pinnacles, trefoil arches) around God’s throne

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, extremely smooth surface with visible hair-follicle pattern; regular quaternion gathering; margins approx. 2.5 cm all around
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation (particularly ultramarine and lead white); slight pigment flaking in small areas of vermillion; minor parchment cockling at lower edge; evidence of modern consolidation in gold-leaf areas
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf with punched dot pattern
Confident underdrawing visible under UV in brown ink
Regular ruling in plummet for image panel boundaries

secondary_functions: Memory aid for the saint’s feast
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual patron (noble or cleric) using a personal devotional book

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature likely originates from a mid-13th-century Parisian workshop specialized in high-quality devotional manuscripts. The hierarchical composition, with God enthroned in micro-architecture above and an angel mediating between heaven and earth, reflects theological doctrines of soul reception and intercession prevalent in Dominican and Franciscan circles. The use of burnished gold and ultramarine signals both the manuscript’s luxury status and the sacred nature of the depicted event. Stylistically, the work exhibits the influence of the English Channel School in its linear contours and diaper-patterned ground, while the refined underdrawing and precision of gesso relief suggest collaboration among a master illuminator and a specialist gilding assistant. Iconographically, the image underscores the triumphant fate of martyrs, their souls borne aloft through angelic service—an emphasis aligned with the increasing cult of saints in the later thirteenth century. Comparisons with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile reveal similar border motifs, indicating a shared repertoire of decorative patterns across royal and aristocratic commissions. Technically, the miniature demonstrates sophisticated layering of pigments, meticulous punchwork in the gold, and careful parchment preparation, marking it as a product of a court-influenced atelier. Overall, the illumination embodies the intersection of innovation and tradition in Gothic manuscript art, articulating complex theological messages through a clear hierarchical visual program.
